question_text: In propositional logic, what is a tautology?
correct_answer: A formula that is true under every possible interpretation of its component terms.
distractors: A formula that is true under at least one interpretation but may be false under others.
A formula whose truth value cannot be determined without knowing the specific model chosen.
A formula that is false under every possible interpretation of its component terms.

question_text: What is the role of logical connectives such as conjunction, disjunction, and implication in propositional logic?
correct_answer: They combine or modify propositions to form compound statements whose truth values are determined by their components.
distractors: They assign numerical values to variables so that algebraic equations can be solved systematically.
They quantify over individuals in a domain, specifying whether a property holds for all or some members.
They establish identity relations between objects, allowing substitution of equals for equals in formulas.

question_text: Who initiated the modern study of set theory in the 1870s, establishing the mathematical investigation of collections of objects?
correct_answer: Georg Cantor, together with Richard Dedekind, initiated the modern study of set theory.
distractors: Gottlob Frege and Giuseppe Peano, through their development of formal predicate logic and arithmetic axioms.
Bertrand Russell and Alfred North Whitehead, through their construction of Principia Mathematica.
David Hilbert and Ernst Zermelo, through their axiomatization of geometry and foundational programs.

question_text: In proof by contradiction (reductio ad absurdum), how is a statement established as true?
correct_answer: By assuming the statement's negation and showing that this assumption leads to a logical contradiction.
distractors: By constructing a direct chain of deductions from accepted axioms to the statement itself.
By verifying the statement holds in every possible case through exhaustive enumeration.
By proving a base case and then showing that if it holds for n it also holds for n+1.

question_text: In logic, what distinguishes a sound argument from one that is merely valid?
correct_answer: A sound argument is valid and all of its premises are actually true, thereby guaranteeing a true conclusion.
distractors: A sound argument uses only deductive reasoning, whereas a merely valid argument may rely on inductive steps.
A sound argument has been formally verified using a complete truth table for every connective it contains.
A sound argument contains no more than two premises, whereas a valid argument may contain any number.

question_text: What truth conditions define the logical biconditional connective (P if and only if Q)?
correct_answer: It is true when both P and Q share the same truth value and false when their truth values differ.
distractors: It is true whenever P is true, regardless of the truth value of Q.
It is true whenever at least one of P or Q is true and false only when both are false.
It is true except when both P and Q are true, and false otherwise.

question_text: What does Goedel's completeness theorem (1929) establish about first-order logic?
correct_answer: Every logically valid first-order formula is provable from the standard axioms and inference rules of first-order logic.
distractors: Every true statement of arithmetic can be formally proved within Peano arithmetic.
No consistent formal system strong enough to encode arithmetic can prove its own consistency.
First-order logic is decidable, meaning an algorithm exists to determine the validity of any formula.

question_text: In modal logic, what do the box operator and the diamond operator represent?
correct_answer: The box denotes necessity (necessarily P) and the diamond denotes possibility (possibly P); they are dual operators.
distractors: The box denotes universal quantification over individuals and the diamond denotes existential quantification.
The box denotes logical conjunction of propositions and the diamond denotes logical disjunction.
The box denotes obligation (P ought to be the case) and the diamond denotes knowledge (P is known).

question_text: In Kripke semantics for modal logic, what two components constitute a Kripke frame?
correct_answer: A non-empty set W of possible worlds and a binary accessibility relation R between those worlds.
distractors: A set of propositional variables and a truth-value assignment function mapping each variable to true or false.
A domain of individuals and a set of predicate symbols together with their interpretations.
A collection of axiom schemas and a set of inference rules for deriving modal theorems.

question_text: Who developed the natural deduction proof system, and what is its central organizing principle?
correct_answer: Gerhard Gentzen developed it in the 1930s; it is organized around paired introduction and elimination rules for each logical connective.
distractors: Alfred Tarski developed it in the 1920s; it is organized around semantic truth definitions for formal languages.
Gottlob Frege developed it in the 1870s; it is organized around axiom schemas with modus ponens as the sole inference rule.
Alan Turing developed it in the 1940s; it is organized around mechanical decision procedures for determining formula validity.
